awd_titl_txt: Engaging Non-Science Majors in Authentic Research through Citizen Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The nation's welfare depends on the ability of people to understand scientific information and make sense of data. Introductory science courses are often the last formal science course taken by undergraduate students who are not majoring in science. In many of these introductory science courses, students gain little insight into what scientists do and how science works. It is therefore important for introductory courses to provide opportunities for students to better understand how science works, and to gain skills using and analyzing data. In this project, curricula will be developed and tested for introductory astronomy, biology, and geoscience courses to involve students in citizen science research projects. Students will actively participate in the online citizen science platform, Zooniverse, and conduct group research projects of their own design. The Zooniverse platform allows scientists to work with amateur volunteers on authentic research. It contains over 80 active citizen science projects on a variety of topics and provides quality curated data with user-friendly data analysis tools. This project aims to create opportunities for students to carry out work to support scientific discovery and reach evidence-based conclusions. Through these experiences, it is expected that students will improve their scientific knowledge and scientific thinking skills.

This project aims to develop, implement, and assess citizen science research experiences in introductory science courses for non-science majors. Curricular materials will be developed for introductory astronomy, biology, and geoscience courses at five different types of institutions. The proposed materials will engage students with in-class activities and group research projects. These activities will use the Zooniverse online platform to engage students in classifying data, assessing data reliability, and using scientific approaches to explore the data in a real-world context. Materials developed in this project will be informed by evidence-based practices associated with course based undergraduate research experiences. The effort will build on the project teams' prior work to integrate Zooniverse-based research experiences in introductory astronomy courses. The team will assess ease of use and implementation of the research experiences across the disciplinary content, institutional contexts, and course structures. The impact on students' learning and attitudinal gains will be assessed using pre/post surveys, coded assignments, interviews with students, and embedded assessments within the Zooniverse platform. The outcomes that will be assessed include changes in science self-efficacy, science identity, ability to make claims and reason with evidence, and potential for lifelong science engagement. Project results will be widely disseminated, and all materials will be publicly available via classroom.zooniverse.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Throughout the 3-year duration of the award, we have developed and assessed the impact of three citizen science-based classroom investigations for undergraduate students enrolled in introductory astronomy, biology, geoscience, and environmental science courses. Each year, hundreds of thousands of students enroll in introductory science courses to fulfill their institution's liberal arts requirement. These courses are often students' last formal exposure to the scientific discipline before they graduate and become voters, teachers, policy makers, and global citizens. To this end, our goal throughout the duration of this award was to generate data-driven inquiry experiences that allowed students to contribute to science in a meaningful way via citizen science. By exposing them to citizen science projects hosted on the Zooniverse platform (www.zoonivese.org), we aimed to break the barrier between students' perceptions of science as a discipline exclusive to individuals in lab coats with years of experience. Furthermore, we aimed to increase students' self-efficacy, data fluency, and disciplinary understanding of topics at the forefront of current astronomical and earth science research programs. 

In the first two years of the effort, we developed a framework-based, three-part curricular model used to inform the development of two 75-90 minute classroom activities highlighting two Zooniverse projects; Planet Hunters (www.planethunters.org) and Floatings Forests (www.floatingforests.org). Each of these activities began with a tutorial style approach to introduce students to the activity's central topic (transiting exoplanets and climate change, respectively). Students then worked through practice modules that were nearly identical to the true Planet Hunters and Floating Forests interfaces but with curated datasets where students could complete a task and then receive feedback. Subsequently, students contributed to the actual citizen science projects central to the investigation. Both activities ended with a guided data-driven inquiry experience where students grappled with actual scientific datasets to answer a research question presented at the start of the investigation. The Planet Hunters activity was tested with 1,099 students at 9 institutions and the Floating Forests activity was tested with 1,405 students at 6 institutions. The pilot sites in the study represented a range of institution types, from small to large, public to private, R1 to liberal arts colleges, community colleges and minority serving institutions. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, both the Floating Forests and Planet Hunters activities were implemented exclusively in online courses via Google Docs. 

A self-efficacy-based assessment given to students at the start of the course and again after completing either the Planet Hunters or Floating Forest Activity (depending on the discipline) indicated statistically significant improvement in students' perceptions of their data literacy skills in addition to their ability to make meaningful contributions to scientific research. For the Floating Forests activity specifically, the assessment also showed statistically significant increases in students' overall perceptions of the impact of climate change. An additional layer of preliminary analysis showed that prior to completing the Floating Forests Activity, black/African and hispanic/latino students self-reported lower trust in scientific research than white and asian students. However, following completion of our activity, trust in scientific research increased proportionately more in the black/African and hispanic/latino students such that post-activity trust in science was similar across all four ethnicities. This is something that we would be interested in exploring further in the future with a more targeted assessment. Instructors interviewed about these two activities consistently reported that they were easy to implement into their existing courses, aligned well with their course goals, and had the potential for widespread dissemination and use. 

In the final year of the effort, we developed and assessed an additional classroom activity designed for in-person, introductory geoscience courses highlighting the Zooniverse project, Planet Four (www.planetfour.org). Although this activity followed a similar, three-part, curricular model, it also incorporated best practices from culturally responsive curriculum development. This activity gave students many opportunities to reflect back on their own lived experiences and to share opinions about future crewed versus uncrewed missions to Mars. The overarching goal of the Planet Four activity was to use Mars' atmosphere as a simple model to learn about the role of carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere. This activity was tested with nearly 500 students at 7 different institutions. Although the data analysis portion of student survey responses is ongoing, preliminary findings indicate that the Planet Four activity increased students' sense of belonging in science, and that the incorporation of culturally responsive components to the activity was a welcomed addition.

At the end of the 3-year duration of the award, the research team has produced 3 peer-reviewed publications (1 published, 1 submitted/in-review, 1 to be submitted Spring 2023), 2 conference proceedings, 4 invited workshops (1 international), 11 oral conference presentations (3 invited, 1 international), and 4 additional invited professional talks (1 international).
